You’re remote to me

Working with remote teams isn’t easy, but it’s inevitable with any growing organization. I’ve worked remotely in 3 different organizations — opening my startup’s offices in London and Singapore, as 18F’s first employee in the San Francisco office, and from Medium’s New York City office. Despite being completely different organizations, none cracked the nut on remote teams.

I scratched my head. Why is the experience of the remote worker always so horrendous? Then it dawned on me. We’re thinking of remote work the wrong way. Even the term “remote” stigmatizes people not physically next to you. What is their perspective? How do I feel when working remotely? Then I realized…

They’re remote to me.

Let’s say you’re sitting at headquarters in San Francisco, on a video call with someone in New York. Realize that, from the perspective of the other person, you’re remote! When you internalize this observation, your perspective changes. You start asking if Jacob in New York has anything to add. Or mention that Josie in Singapore has a great idea we should consider, and yield the floor.

When working with remote teams, here’s a few things I’ve learned that I hope help you too.

Make it easy for remote teams to join. You know where your colleagues work and when they’re at work. I’m sure their calendar tells you when they’re busy or OOO. Add a remote dial in, a Google hangout, or whatever your team uses. If they decline, you can carry out the meeting as usual. Turn Google Hangouts on for your organization by default (many admins have disabled this feature, sadly).

Remote connections have a delay. It is amazing how many people don’t realize this. From our NY to SF office there can be a 3 to 5 second delay. Whenever you start to talk, you end up talking over a conversation that started 5 seconds ago. Pause. Prompt them. Most importantly, wait. Embrace the awkward silence. Go around the virtual room. If you think it is hard to get a word in at a meeting, imagine the frustration of those not physically in the room.

Remote technology is annoying. Obviously, being remote isn’t as good as being there in person. You’re annoyed that the audio or video keeps cutting out on that person? Guess what? It’s doing the same for the other person. Be flexible. Pick up your cell phone and call them. Be patient. These are your teammates. Gain empathy for your teammates — conduct all your meetings as if they were remote. You may not notice how important the small things are until you try it yourself.

Test it out. Part of your organization’s on-boarding should be figuring out your remote tools. We all hate fumbling through tools, switching, and losing time. But again, be patient and switch quickly. Stop fussing with a broken system.

Slack is not a substitute. Have you ever tried to catch up on thousands of messages in #general because you went home for the day at your normal time (or God forbid, went on vacation)? Slack is not a replacement for properly communicating. Don’t expect anyone has read what you wrote on Slack unless you DM’d them.

Be on time. There’s nothing more frustrating than staring at an empty room or an unanswered hangout.

And most importantly, if it wasn’t clear already, be patient and be respectful. You’re just as remote to the other person as they are to you.
